docs.abstract: Comment on trend in some restaurants of lacing food with cigar and pipe tobacco; scientists caution that tobacco used in certain dishes could make nonsmokers sick; photo (M
docs.lead_paragraph: THE latest fad in cooking has some scientists upset enough to blurt out very unscientific remarks. ''I've heard of stupid things in my life, and you can quote me,'' said Dr. David A. Kessler, dean of the Yale University School of Medicine, when he heard about the trend of lacing food with cigar and pipe tobacco. Tobacco is a hot-button issue, and scientists who have spent much of their lives trying to get people to stop smoking see red when another way of consuming it is suggested. Chefs who use pipe and cigar tobacco say it imparts a certain spiciness. But some scientists caution that an occasional dessert made with tobacco sauce or tobacco cream might make a nonsmoker sick.
